legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Business Enterprise Research and Development

title.text: You are completing this for {trad_as} ({ru_name})

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: You have been selected to complete the Business Enterprise Research and Development (BERD) survey.
The purpose of this survey is to collect expenditure and employment figures relating to Research and Development (R&D) activities.

The survey contributes to the measurement of resources devoted to R&D in the United Kingdom (UK). These figures are used in analysis and decision making by government, businesses and international organisations and are collected to allow the UK to be internationally comparable with other R&D performing countries.
You should report R&D expenditure figures regardless of whether tax credits have been claimed.
Data should relate to all sites in the UK. The UK includes England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland but excludes the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.

contents.description: If your business did not perform or purchase any R&D, you are still required to complete the relevant sections in this questionnaire.
This questionnaire is divided into sections, which ask for information about:
This section asks about the period for which your business will be reporting.

Your return period should cover the calendar year 2023. If no figures are available for that 12 month period, your return should relate to a business year that ends between 6 April 2023 and 5 April 2024.

This section asks for information about the R&D that your business has undertaken either for yourself or for a customer. This is the total cost of R&D conducted by your business, regardless of the source of funds or their treatment within your business's accounts.
This includes:

list: non-capital expenditure on in-house R&D
capital expenditure on in-house R&D
funding for expenditure on in-house R&D
ownership of R&D assets

questions.question: Purchase of R&D conducted outside the business

contents.description: This section asks for information about the purchase of R&D from outside the business. This can include R&D work both within and outside the UK as well as work originally commissioned by Government.

questions.question: Number of employees working on R&D

contents.description: This section asks for information about how many employees worked on R&D during the reporting period and how many full-time equivalents work on R&D.
This section asks for information about:

list: the postcodes of all the workplaces within the business where in-house R&D is performed
the percentage of the business's total R&D carried out at each workplace

contents.description: All workplaces, covering 100% of the business's in-house R&D should be reported.
R&D covers three types of activity:

list: basic research
applied research
experimental development

contents.description: R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:
Novel - to be aimed at new findings
Creative - to be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
Uncertain - to be uncertain about the final outcome
Systematic - to be planned and budgeted
Transferable or reproducible - to lead to results that could possibly be reproduced

blocks.page_title: Reporting period

contents.description: This page contains some basic guidelines to help define and measure R&D for the completion of this survey. In some cases, you may need to apply judgement when compiling figures. Informed estimates are acceptable. Further information can be found in the Frascati Manual (this link opens in a new tab), which is the international source of methodology for collecting and using R&D statistics.
R&D covers three types of activity:

list: basic research
applied research
experimental development

contents.description: R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:
Novel - to be aimed at new findings
Creative - to be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
Uncertain - to be uncertain about the final outcome
Systematic - to be planned and budgeted
Transferable or reproducible - to lead to results that could possibly be reproduced

list: clinical trials phases I, II and III
social sciences, arts and humanities research work, such as, behavioural insights, linguistics and development of ethical processes

research into and original development, or substantial modification, of computer software and related hardware, such as, new programming languages and new operating systems, including Artificial Intelligence, Augmented Reality, Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) and Apps
design, construction and operation of prototypes where the main objective is technical testing or to make further improvements
construction and operation of pilot plants while still in the experimental phase and the primary purpose of operation is non-commercial
'feedback R&D' directed at solving problems occurring beyond the original R&D phase, such as, the resolution of technical problems arising in initial production runs

contents.description: Unless used primarily as part of, or for the support of R&D projects, the following are excluded:

list: clinical trial phase IV
scientific and technical information services
prospecting, exploring or drilling for minerals, petroleum or natural gas
policy related studies, management studies, efficiency studies
consumer surveys, advertising, market research
routine quality control and testing
general purpose or routine data collection
feasibility studies
routine computer programming, systems maintenance or software application
commercial, legal and administrative aspects of patenting, copyrighting or licensing activities
activities associated with standards compliance
specialised routine medical care, for example, routine pathology services

contents.description: R&D ends when the work is no longer experimental, for example, when the material or product is substantially developed and the primary objective is to:

list: develop markets
plan for pre-production and undertake pre-production activities, such as, demonstration of commercial viability, tooling up and trial production runs
get production or control systems working smoothly

contents.description: If the primary objective is to make further technical improvements, then the work is still defined as R&D.

description.text: You will be asked to report for {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}. If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.

contents.description: You still need to complete this survey even if it does not seem relevant, you will only need to complete a limited selection of questions.

It is just as important for us to know if you did not perform or purchase any R&D during the reporting period, to ensure we accurately measure R&D in the UK. All returns are important as it helps us produce better statistics.

Only commenced trading during 2023?

Ceased trading during 2023?
Your return should cover the period 1 January 2023 to the date you ceased to trade or, alternatively, from the beginning of your last business year up to the cessation date.

title.text: For the reporting period, of the {total_capital_and_noncapital_expenditure_on_inhouse_civil_rampd} total expenditure for in-house civil R&D, how much of your business's R&D assets are, or will be, owned by the following?

description.text:
You are reporting civil R&D for code {product_codes}.

For this question, the value of the R&D assets your business produces should be allocated to owners, or future and final owners.

Values should sum to your business's total in-house expenditure for civil R&D.

Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

Informed estimates are acceptable. It may be necessary to consider individual R&D projects and then aggregate results.

contents.description: Exclude any cost plus element

answers.label: Your UK business
answers.description: Include your parent company, other subsidiary companies operating within the UK, or R&D covered by patents owned by your UK business

answers.label: The UK Government
answers.description: Include UK government departments, their agencies and non-departmental public bodies, for example, NHS, MoD, DSIT, the Scottish or Welsh Governments and UK Research and Innovation (UKRI). Exclude European funding departments, such as, the Welsh European Funding Office (WEFO)

answers.label: Other UK business enterprises
answers.description: Include non-profit organisations serving businesses

answers.label: Other UK organisations
answers.description: Include higher education establishments and private non-profit organisations serving households, education establishments and trade unions

answers.label: Any other businesses or organisations outside the UK
answers.description: Include businesses within your group but outside the UK, for example, funded from your parent company or other subsidiary companies operating outside the UK; other business enterprises outside of the UK; non-UK governments; international organisations, for example, World Trade Organisation or NATO and the Commission of the European Union

answers.label: Not owned and freely available in-house Research and Development
answers.description: Include in-house R&D which is developed and published and made freely available for others to use. For example, publications in journals or on the internet, and R&D with no intellectual property protection, such as, patents and copyrights

guidance.show_guidance: How you might answer this question
guidance.hide_guidance: How you might answer this question

contents.description: If the R&D performed in the reporting period is, or is expected to eventually be, subject to intellectual property protection, such as, patents and copyrights, the holder of that protection is the owner.
If a number of organisations will own the R&D assets, the in-house expenditure should be divided and allocated to the relevant owners.

If ownership is contractually divided between different owners, divide the in-house R&D in accordance with the percentage ownership. For example, 60% is owned by your UK business and 40% owned by the UK Government, please use these percentages to divide the in-house R&D expenditure between answers.

If no contractual arrangements exist, the value of the assets should be divided according to your best estimate of their use. For example, if your business and another organisation are both owners, but your business will use the assets more, ownership should be allocated accordingly. If the use cannot be estimated, the assets should be divided equally between the owners.

blocks.page_title: Number of employees working on R&D

content.title: Number of employees working on R&D

contents.description: This section asks for information about how many employees and full-time equivalents work on R&D.

An employee is anyone aged 16 years or over who is working directly for the business. They may be paid direct from the business, from elsewhere within the wider group, or by an external payroll provider on behalf of the company. If your business uses a central payroll to pay employees who work within the wider group, only include employees working directly for the business.

question.title: On 1 December 2023, how many employees working on R&D were researchers?
description: 'Researchers' refers to employees who are engaged in conception or creation of new knowledge, products, methods and systems. For example, PhD students, graduates and scientists.

contents.description: Include:

list: full-time (over 30 hours a week) and part-time (30 hours or less) employees aged 16 years and over. This includes individuals working from home and those temporarily absent but still employed, for example those on parental leave or sick leave
those on apprenticeships or training schemes
directors and working owners paid via PAYE
employees without guaranteed hours, for example those on zero hour contracts, who worked on this date

contents.description: Exclude:

list: workers paid by an employment agency, for example consultants and contingent labour
voluntary workers
former employees only receiving a pension
self-employed workers
directors and working owners who are not paid via PAYE

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, how many full-time equivalent employees working on R&D were researchers?

description:
'Researchers' refers to employees who are engaged in conception or creation of new knowledge, products, methods and systems. For example, PhD students, graduates and scientists.

One full-time equivalent (FTE) may be thought of as one person-year.

For example, a person who normally spends 30% of their time on R&D and the rest on other activities should be considered as 0.3 FTE.

Similarly, if a full-time R&D worker is employed at an R&D unit for only six months, this results in the FTE of 0.5.

contents.description: Include:

list: full-time (over 30 hours a week) and part-time (30 hours or less) employees aged 16 years and over. This includes individuals working from home and those temporarily absent but still employed, for example those on parental leave or sick leave
those on apprenticeships or training schemes
directors and working owners paid via PAYE
employees without guaranteed hours, for example those on zero hour contracts, who worked on this date

contents.description: Exclude:

list: workers paid by an employment agency, for example consultants and contingent labour
voluntary workers
former employees only receiving a pension
self-employed workers
directors and working owners who are not paid via PAYE
